text: Even on Earth itself, the largest bulk of our biosphere— including deep sediments and rock strata—consists of microbial ecosystems.
Reduced iron (Fe2+) from rock is oxidized through weathering or mining.
Oxidized iron (Fe3+) serves as a terminal electron acceptor in anaerobic soil and water.

In fact, a case can be made that the majority of biospheres in our galaxy would consist entirely of microbial life, since microbes inhabit a wider range of conditions than do multicellular plants and animals.
Bacterial lithotrophy accelerates iron oxidation, leading to Metal toxins can be metabolized by bacteria.
The same fundamental molecules that appear in early-Earth simulation experiments, such as adenine and glycine, also appear in meteorites.
Metabolic conversion to an insoluble form, such as arsenite to arsenate, offers an effective means of Marine habitats show resource colimitation.
Multiple resources may be limiting for the phytoplankton community or for different populations.
Phosphate limits growth of phototrophic bacteria and algae in some aquatic and marine Iron cycles in oxidized and reduced forms.
If life is found on other planets, it will almost certainly include microbes.
On the other hand, if life could indeed be founded on some other basis, how would we recognize it?
Thus, we suspect that the fundamental building blocks for biochemistry are universal.
Bacterial metabolism may either increase or decrease toxicity.
Phosphorus cycles primarily in the fully oxidized form (phosphate).
